children.subject: <md>FWIW I have found CS 61C to be on par with CS 61A/B in terms of workload this semester -- maybe even easier. I had a little bit of experience in performance programming in C going in, but that maybe wasn't a huge factor. The projects only take like 2-4 days each, and there are only 4 of them, and the course staff has been working hard to make everything easy to debug, _and_ they now have safeguards in place to make sure the labs don't take much more than 2 hours.</md>

history.content: Hmm, I wouldn't say the workload has "significantly decreased" - for the most part, the assignments are the same as earlier semesters, and the content itself hasn't really changed, but we've been working on backend improvements to the tools we give you so that it's easier to use the debugging tools to help yourself when you get stuck on a bug. It's still one of the densest classes at Berkeley in terms of how much material we cover, so I'd still expect 61C over summer to take a couple hours of work per day. It's really up to your time management and other commitments over summer for whether that's feasible.

<md>Given the current enrollment restrictions on 61C, I signed up for summer 61C because I would most likely not get into the class in Fall. However, I also have an in-person internship over the summer. How feasible is doing an internship along with 61C over summer? I've heard that the workload in 61C has significantly decreased and is more manageable, and I'm planning to self study some of the material before session C begins. </md>
history.subject: Summer CS61C + Internship
